questions.text: A 12-year-old male child presents to the clinic with a history of progressive hearing loss, blurred vision, and recurrent episodes of hematuria over the past few months.Electron microscopy reveals the ‘basketweave’ appearance of GBM. Which of the following morphological findings is responsible for this appearance?

choices.text: Thickening of the glomerular basement membrane with subepithelial electron-dense deposits
Irregular thickening, thinning, and splitting of the glomerular basement membrane
Mesangial expansion with GBM thickening and eosinophilic nodular glomerulosclerosis

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Irregular thickening, thinning, and splitting of the glomerular basement membrane

 

Explanation:

The clinical presentation and EM findings of the characteristic basket-weave appearance of GBM suggest Alport syndrome arises due to mutations affecting type IV collagen, resulting in hematuria progressing to chronic renal insufficiency.

  • It presents alongside sensorineural hearing impairment and various ocular manifestations, including lens subluxation, posterior subcapsular cataracts, and corneal dystrophy.
  • Histologically, Alport syndrome shows distinct electron microscopic features:
    • GBM exhibits irregular areas of thickening interspersed with thinning.
    • Splitting and layering of the lamina densa (basket-weave appearance of GBM)

 

Effacement of podocyte foot processes (Option A)

Effacement of podocytes is characteristically seen in Minimal change disease, not the Alport syndrome.

Thickening of the glomerular basement membrane with subepithelial electron-dense deposits (Option B)

Membranous nephropathy shows the thickening of the glomerular basement membrane without hypercellularity on light microscopy, while electron microscopy shows the ‘spike and dome’ appearance of subepithelial deposits.

 

Mesangial expansion with GBM thickening and eosinophilic nodular glomerulosclerosis (Option D)

Diabetic glomerulonephropathy shows mesangial expansion with GBM thickening and eosinophilic nodular glomerulosclerosis (Kimmelstiel-Wilson lesions)

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient with a history of poorly controlled diabetes presents with worsening kidney function. Upon examination, renal biopsy reveals glomerular changes consistent with diabetic nephropathy. Which histological findings would be least likely to be observed in the glomeruli of this patient's kidney biopsy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Armani-Ebstein lesion

 

Explanation:

In uncontrolled diabetes, glucosuria causes glycogen accumulation in the proximal tubular cells (not in the glomerulus), known as Armanni-Ebstein cells. This pathological finding is more commonly associated with diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) than with diabetic nephropathy.

Incorrect options explanation

 

Kimmelstiel-Wilson nodule (Option A)

Kimmelstiel-Wilson nodules (aka Nodular glomerulosclerosis) are a hallmark of diabetic nephropathy. They are ovoid or spherical, PAS-positive nodules found in the mesangial core of glomeruli. They are often accompanied by mesangiolysis and sometimes surrounded by dilated capillary loops.

Diffuse glomerulosclerosis (Option B)

Diffuse glomerulosclerosis refers to a diffuse increase in the mesangial matrix and thickening of GBM. It correlates with deteriorating renal function and increasing proteinuria.

  • This is the most common histopathological finding of diabetic nephropathy.

Arteriolar hyalinosis (Option C)

  • Arteriolar hyalinosis involves the accumulation of hyaline material in the walls of both afferent and efferent arterioles, contributing to ischemia and kidney damage in diabetes.
  • Hyaline material accumulated in capillary loops is known as “fibrin caps” in Bowman’s capsule, it is called “capsular drops.”

questions.text: A 32-year-old female presents with a history of joint pain, skin rash, and recent onset of shortness of breath. Lab investigations reveal elevated anti-double-stranded DNA antibodies and low complement levels. A kidney biopsy shows >50% involvement of glomeruli with wire loop lesions on light microscopy. Which type of lupus nephritis is most likely observed in the biopsy findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Class IV

 

Explanation:

Based on the clinical scenario and lab results, the patient likely has systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) with renal involvement. The kidney biopsy revealing >50% glomerular involvement with wire loop lesions indicates class IV lupus nephritis, the most common and severe form.

Classification of Lupus Nephritis (LN):

 

Class I

Minimal Mesangial LN

Class II

Mesangial proliferative LN

Class III (Option A)

Focal LN (<50% glomeruli)

Class IV

Diffuse LN (>50% glomeruli)

Class V (Option C)

Membranous LN

Class VI (Option D)

Advanced Sclerosing LN

 

Light microscopy: Subendothelial immune complex deposits can result in the circumferential thickening of the capillary wall, leading to the formation of "wire loop" structures, which are observed in Class III, IV (maximum) and V.

Electron microscopy: Thumbprint/ fingerprint sign (alternating areas of electron-dense deposits and lucent regions in GBM, indicating immune complex deposition)

Immunofluorescence: Full House Effect (IgG, IgA, IgM, C1, C3 get deposited in the kidney)

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with generalised oedema and frothy urine. Laboratory investigations reveal significant proteinuria and hypoalbuminemia. A kidney biopsy reveals diffuse thickening of GBM, a spike and dome pattern on the silver stain and subepithelial deposits on electron microscopy. Which of the following genetic mutations is most likely associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Mutation in PLA2R

 

Explanation:

The clinical presentation, along with the histological findings of diffuse thickening of GBM, a spike and dome pattern on the silver stain, and subepithelial deposits on electron microscopy, suggest Membranous nephropathy, the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in elderly patients.

  • In primary membranous nephropathy, antibodies primarily target the M-type phospholipase A2 receptor (PLA2R) located on the basal surface of podocytes. This triggers complement activation and subepithelial immune complex deposition, resembling Heymann nephritis lesions.
  • Other less common target antigens include THSD7A and neutral endopeptidase (CD10).
  • The presence of anti-PLA2R antibodies is crucial for diagnosing the disease.

questions.text: Which genetic mutation is responsible for a syndrome of steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome of childhood onset?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) NPHS2

 

Explanation:

The above clinical scenario points towards the diagnosis of steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome, which is defined as the absence of remission despite 4 weeks of therapy with daily prednisone at a dose of 2 mg/kg/d.

  • Mutations in the NPHS2 gene lead to this syndrome, typically manifesting in childhood.
  • The NPHS2 gene is located on chromosome 1q25–q31.
  • The NPHS2 gene encodes the protein product known as podocin which is localised to the slit diaphragm within the kidney.
  • Patients typically present from birth to 6 years of age have a steroid-resistant course and reach End-stage Renal Disease (ESRD) before the end of their first decade.

 

NPHS1 (Option A)

NPHS1 mutations are associated with congenital nephrotic syndrome of the Finnish type.

 

α-actinin 4 (Option C)

Mutations in the gene encoding the podocyte actin-binding protein α-actinin 4 (ACTN4) underlie some cases of autosomal dominant focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS), which tends to have a high rate of progression to renal insufficiency.

 

TRPC6 (Option D)

Mutations in the TRPC6 gene, which encodes a calcium-permeable ion channel in podocytes, have been identified in some cases of familial FSGS. However, TRPC6 mutations are not typically linked to childhood-onset steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with swelling around his eyes, ankles, and abdomen, along with frothy urine. Urinalysis shows proteinuria, elevated serum creatinine, and BUN levels. Image of renal biopsy is given below. Which of the following is not an established cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Diabetes mellitus

Explanation:

Based on the given clinical scenario and HPE image (segmental sclerosis, glomerular hyalinosis, and tubular atrophy, with negative immunofluorescence), the most likely diagnosis is Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis (FSGS), the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in adults.

Diabetes mellitus primarily causes diabetic nephropathy, characterised by diffuse glomerulosclerosis rather than the focal and segmental pattern seen in FSGS.

 

Causes of FSGS:

1. Primary (Idiopathic) FSGS.

2. Secondary FSGS: Mnemonic- H3R3S1

  • Hypertension (Option C)
  • HIV associated nephropathy (Option B)
  • Heroine drug abuse
  • Reflux nephropathy
  • Renal tissue loss
  • Sickle cell anaemia (Option D)

3. Inherited forms:

  • Genetic mutations affecting slit diaphragm proteins like nephrin, podocin, α-actinin 4, and TRPC6.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents with sudden generalised oedema and frothy urine. Urinalysis reveals heavy proteinuria without hematuria. Renal biopsy widespread effacement of podocyte foot processes on electron microscopy. Which of the following is true regarding this condition?

choices.text: Lipid deposition within glomerular capillaries (tubular cells)
Immunofluorescence microscopy reveals granular deposition of IgG and C3 in the glomeruli.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Good response to corticosteroid therapy

 

Explanation:

  • The clinical and electron microscope findings suggest the diagnosis as Minimal Change Disease (MCD), characterised by diffuse effacement of foot processes of podocytes in glomeruli. It primarily affects children aged 2-6 years.
  • MCD typically responds rapidly to corticosteroid therapy, especially in children (>90%), leading to complete remission of proteinuria and resolution of symptoms.

 

Lipid deposition within glomerular capillaries (Option A)

Lipid deposition within glomerular capillaries is not observed in MCD. Instead, protein and lipid deposition may occur in the proximal tubules due to tubular reabsorption of lipoproteins passing through diseased glomeruli, leading to the historical term "lipoid nephrosis" for this disease.

 

Immunofluorescence microscopy reveals granular deposition of IgG and C3 in the glomeruli (Option B)

  • Immunofluorescence studies in MCD typically show no significant immune complex deposition or granular staining patterns.
  • This distinguishes MCD from immune complex-mediated glomerular diseases like IgA nephropathy or lupus nephritis, where IgG and C3 deposits are commonly observed.

 

Non-selective proteinuria (Option D)

Minimal Change Disease (MCD) typically presents with highly selective proteinuria, mostly albumin. Renal function remains good despite massive proteinuria, with no hypertension or hematuria commonly.

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl with a recent upper respiratory tract infection presents with generalised swelling and reduced urine output. Urinalysis reveals proteinuria without blood cells or casts. Electron microscopy findings show flattening, retraction, and swelling of podocytes. Which light microscopy findings is characteristic of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Normal glomeruli

 

Explanation:

The above clinical presentation and EM finding of podocyte effacement is characteristic of Minimal change disease.

  • It is marked by the widespread flattening of podocytes, seen only on electron microscopy, while light microscopy shows normal glomeruli with lipids in proximal tubules.
  • This alteration in podocyte structure leads to increased permeability of the glomerular filtration barrier, resulting in the loss of large amounts of protein in the urine.


 

 

Glomerulosclerosis (Option A)

  • Observed in diabetic nephropathy.
  • Diffuse glomerulosclerosis

              Diffuse glomerulosclerosis                       

Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis

Fibrinoid necrosis in the glomeruli (Option C)

Vasculitis or immune complex-mediated glomerulonephritis.

 

Wire looping of capillaries (Option D)

  • Wire looping of capillaries is seen in diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis, often due to SLE (lupus nephritis).

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman presents with intermittent flank pain and occasional gross hematuria. Physical examination is unremarkable. Laboratory tests show normal renal function. A renal biopsy of a mass lesion reveals a mixture of mature adipose tissue, thick-walled blood vessels, and bundles of smooth muscle cells. All are true regarding this condition except?

choices.text: It is commonly associated with tuberous sclerosis.
It is more prevalent in males than females.
It is mostly a benign tumor.
It has a high susceptibility to spontaneous hemorrhage.

questions.solution:
CORRECT ANSWER:  B)It is more prevalent in males than females.

 

EXPLANATION:

 

Renal angiomyolipoma:

 

  • A benign neoplasm consisting of vessels, smooth muscle, and fat originating from perivascular epithelioid cells. (Option C)
  • It is most often detected incidentally and has a female preponderance. (Option B)
  • They are present in 25% to 50% of patients with tuberous sclerosis. (Option A)
  • It has a high susceptibility for bleeding (can present as loin pain).
  • Morphology:

Histology: Circular blood vessels, muscles, and fat; perivascular epithelioid cells with dense eosinophilic cytoplasm and mitotic figures.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents with complaints of blurred vision, hearing loss, and recurrent episodes of hematuria. Genetic testing reveals a mutation in Type 4 collagen. Which of the following genetic mutations is observed in the patient?
questions.solution:
Answer: D) All of the above

 

Explanation:

Mutations in COL4A3, COL4A4, COL4A5 genes are seen in Alport syndrome.

  • Alport syndrome is caused by defective COL4A3, COL4A4, and COL4A5 genes, which lead to impaired production and deposition of the Type 4 collagen α345 chain network in the basement membranes of the glomerulus, cochlea, and eyes.
  • It is predominantly inherited as an X-linked dominant trait.
  • It has a triad of symptoms.
    • Blurred vision due to Anterior lenticonus, lens dislocation, posterior cataracts, and corneal dystrophy.
    • Recurrent hematuria can lead to renal failure.
    • Bilateral sensorineural hearing loss.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents with painless hematuria post-upper respiratory infections, normal vital signs, and no oedema. Urinalysis reveals red blood cell casts and further investigation shows elevated serum creatinine and mild proteinuria. Renal biopsy confirms glomerulonephritis. What is the most common type of glomerulonephritis in this case?
questions.solution:
Answer: A) IgA nephropathy

 

Explanation:

IgA nephropathy, or Berger’s disease, is the most common type of glomerulonephritis in adults and worldwide.

  • It presents with gross hematuria in adults, usually 2-3 days after an upper respiratory infection.
  • It can progress to acute renal failure, causing ankle oedema, facial puffiness, and hypertension.
  • It occurs due to the formation of aberrant IgA molecules that deposit in the mesangial regions.

 

 

 

Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (Option B)

  • It is the most common type of glomerulonephritis in children and presents with fever, oliguria, hypertension, periorbital oedema, and hematuria.
  • It usually occurs 1 to 2 weeks after recovery from an upper respiratory infection, which causes an inflammatory response (type III hypersensitivity reaction).

 

Minimal change disease (Option C)

  • It is the most common type of nephrotic syndrome in children.
  • It presents with massive proteinuria(>3.5g/24hrs) due to immunological damage to epithelial cells.

 

Membranous nephropathy (Option D)

  • It is the most common type of nephrotic syndrome in the elderly.
  • It is immune complex-mediated and can be caused by malignancy(colon, lung, melanoma), infections(malaria, hepatitis B, C, syphilis, schistosomiasis), drugs(gold, penicillamine), or autoimmune conditions(SLE).

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with recurrent hematuria following upper respiratory infections and intermittent proteinuria. Renal biopsy shows mesangial IgA deposits on immunofluorescence and electron-dense deposits in the mesangium on electron microscopy. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Answer: A) Berger’s Disease

Explanation:

The clinical and histopathological findings suggest the diagnosis of Berger’s disease or IgA nephropathy, characterised by the deposition of IgA antibodies in the mesangial regions of the glomeruli, leading to recurrent episodes of hematuria.

  • Electron microscopy reveals electron-dense deposits predominantly localised in the mesangium.
  • The characteristic immunofluorescent picture shows mesangial deposition of IgA, often with C3 and properdin and lesser amounts of IgG or IgM.

 

Alport syndrome (Option B)

  • It is a genetic disorder characterised by abnormalities in type IV collagen, leading to progressive kidney disease, hearing loss, and eye abnormalities.
  • Electron microscopy reveals irregular thickening of the glomerular basement membrane with lamellation and splitting.

 

Membranous nephropathy (Option C)

It is caused by the deposition of immune complexes (primarily IgG and C3) on the outer (subepithelial) side of the glomerular basement membrane.

 

Buerger's Disease (Option D)

  • It is also called Thromboangiitis obliterans, it is a vascular disease causing extremity ischemia and is unrelated to renal involvement or immune deposits in the kidney.
  • It does not present with hematuria or proteinuria.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with increasing shortness of breath and hemoptysis. Lab tests show elevated serum creatinine and hematuria. Renal biopsy reveals linear immunofluorescence along the glomerular basement membrane and subepithelial and intramembranous electron-dense deposits on electron microscopy. Which of the following statements regarding the diagnosis is not true?

choices.text: It is a Type III hypersensitivity reaction
Defective α3 chain of collagen IV
Linear immunofluorescence is due to IgG deposition
The most common cause of death is uremia.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) It is a Type III hypersensitivity reaction

 

Explanation:

  • Above mentioned scenario is a case of Goodpasture Syndrome
  • It can be learnt as 1, 2, 3, 4
  1. It is RPGN type 1
  2. It is hypersensitivity type II
  3. and 4. Caused due to antibiotics against alpha 3 chain of type IV collagen.
  • Immunofluorescence shows linear deposit of IgG and C3. (Picture below)
  • Electron microscopy shows rupture and wrinkling of the basement membrane.
  • Clinical Features: Lung involvement- haemoptysis, Renal involvement- haematuria.
  • Most common cause of death: Uremia.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy presents with a recent sore throat, dark urine, fatigue, eye puffiness, and mild limb swelling. Urinalysis reveals hematuria, proteinuria, and red blood cell casts. Serum creatinine levels are slightly elevated. A renal biopsy shows the immunofluorescence image provided below. Which condition is not typically associated with this pattern of rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis?
questions.solution:
Answer: A) Wegeners granulomatosis

 

Explanation:

  • The clinical scenario indicates post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN), a Type 2 RPGN (Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis) associated with granular immunofluorescence.
  • Wegener's granulomatosis is Type 3 RPGN, characterised by pauci-immune glomerulonephritis with no immune deposits.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with a history of SLE presents with fatigue, decreased urine output, and facial swelling. Lab tests show elevated serum creatinine, proteinuria, and hematuria. A renal biopsy is performed, and the histopathological examination image is attached. Which statement is true regarding this condition?

choices.text: >50% of glomeruli showing crescents is diagnostic.
More the number of crescents, better the prognosis.
Crescents are composed solely of endothelial cells.

questions.solution:
Answer: A) >50% of glomeruli showing crescents is diagnostic.

 

Explanation:

The provided clinical scenario and the histopathological image suggest a Rapidly Progressive Glomerulonephritis (RPGN) diagnosis in a patient with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).

Crescentic glomerulonephritis (or RPGN) is characterised by the presence of crescents in more than 50% of glomeruli on renal biopsy.

 

More the number of crescents, the better the prognosis (Option B)

In RPGN, more crescents generally indicate a poor prognosis

 

Crescents are composed solely of endothelial cells (Option C)

Crescents are composed of fibrin, leucocytes, parietal and visceral layers of Bowman capsule.

 

Primarily caused by bacterial infections (Option D)

RPGN Type I, II, III can be due to varied causes.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with dark-coloured urine and puffiness around his eyes following a recent sore throat and skin infection. Laboratory tests show elevated serum creatinine, hematuria, and proteinuria. Renal biopsy image is given below. Which condition is most likely associated with these findings?
questions.solution:
Answer: C) Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis

 

Explanation:

Electron microscope

‘Subepithelial electron-dense humps’ due to immune complex deposition beneath the epithelial cells of the glomerular basement membrane.

Immunofluorescence

Characteristic 'Starry sky appearance' by immune complex deposition.
